questions.text: A 50-year-old man is visiting OPD multiple times for last 6 months with history of increased thirst. The patient has had BP readings of 134/86 mm Hg, 148/96 mm Hg, and 142/90 mm Hg on the last three visits. He has been reluctant to start antihypertensive medications and, instead, has been trying to correct it with exercise and weight loss. His weight has increased by 2 kg. He doesn’t take alcohol and is non-smoker. There is no other significant past medical history. Family h/o-father has coronary artery disease. On examination, BP: 144/92 mm Hg, Heart, Lung, Abdomen: normal findings. Lab reports-plasma random glucose 218 mg/dL; blood urea nitrogen 22 g/dL; creatinine 0.7 mg/dL; CBC: normal, HbA1c: 8.4%, serum LDL cholesterol 145 mg/dL. Urine for microalbumin 120 mg/g. What will you do next

In continuation of previous question,patient was started on metformin,ramipril and atorvastatin.The patient comes for follow up visit after 2 weeks.His symptoms of thirst and polyuria have already improved.He is fully adherent to lifestyle modifications and medicines.You check his BP which is 140/92 mm Hg.His weight is reduced by 2 kg.What will you do next

options.label: A
options.text: Check Hba1c to see average improvement in plasma glucose

options.label: D
options.text: Stop metformin in view of weight loss

questions.text: A 45 year old female recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. She has classical symptoms of weight loss, polydipsia and polyuria. Her plasma glucose is 212 g/dl and 240 g/dl on 2 separate occasions. She has sedentary lifestyle with type A personality. She has no other significant past medical history. She has 2 children without any complications or gestational diabetes during pregnancy. Family history-not significant. On examination her weight is 95 kg with BMI 32,BP-140/88 mmHg. She has acanthosis nigricans, otherwise rest of physical examination is normal. Based on this information what will you do next?

options.label: A
options.text: Diagnose the patient as having diabetes mellitus

options.label: B
options.text: Confirm with oral glucose tolerance test with 75 gm glucose

questions.correct_answer: A. Diagnose the patient as having diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with history of type 2 diabetes for 5 years presented with frothing in urine. He is taking metformin for diabetes. On examination BP is 126/80 mmHg,BMI-30, Other systemic examination is normal. Lab results – HbA1c-7.8 %, serum creatinine- 1.4 mg/dl, urine for microalbumin 250 mg/g. You start the patient on ramipril for microalbuminuria. What is the mechanism of ACE inhibitor benefit for microalbuminuria?

options.label: A
options.text: Dilation of afferent arteriole increases glomerular filtration rate.

options.label: B
options.text: Dilation of efferent arteriole decreases glomerular hypertension.

questions.correct_answer: B. Dilation of efferent arteriole decreases glomerular hypertension.

questions.text: A 68 year old man diagnosed as having type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, CHF and microalbuminuria. The patient is given prescriptions for lisinopril, metformin,thiazide and a statin. A prescription is also given for a home BP monitor and fingerstick glucose monitoring. He tend to skip his meals. He returns in 4 weeks and his BP is 130/80 mm Hg. There is mild pedal edema, lungs/heart examination is normal. His home random glucose test results are: 182 mg/dL, 170 mg/dL, 184 mg/dL, 165 mg/dL. Liver and kidney function tests are normal. Because the patient’s glucose levels are not fully controlled on metformin, you want to add a second agent. He is not willing for any injectable therapy. What will be next appropriate agent

A 54-year-old man, who was diagnosed with diabetes last year, comes to your OPD for a follow-up appointment. He was placed on metformin and a sulfonylurea, which controlled his glucose levels for most of the last year. Currently, he has started to have some episodes of nocturia one to two times a night. He insists he is fully adherent to his medications and lifestyle modifications. Past medical history: Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia, Microalbuminuria, Medications: Metformin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, glimepiride. Current BP – 146/92 mmHg, HbA1c: 7.8% Serum glucose: 195 mg/dL, positive urine microalbumin, liver function tests are normal, LDL: 80 mg/dL. What will you do next

options.label: B
options.text: Add sitagliptin and calcium channel blocker

questions.correct_answer: B. Add sitagliptin and calcium channel blocker

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with a history of type 1 diabetes is brought to the ED by his family for confusion and lethargy for the last day. The patient has been a lifelong diabetic who also has some unclear psychiatric issues. The family says he stopped taking his insulin a few days ago for unclear reasons—he may have just run out of his medications. R: 34 breaths/minute; BP: 106/68 mm Hg; P: 122 beats/minute; T: 99.8°F. PE: General: lethargic, disoriented, rolling around in bed, respiratory distress Chest: clear to auscultation Abdomen: soft, nontender Cardiovascular: no murmur, no gallop Neurological: unable to determine whether there are focal deficits. Glucose 725 mg/dL Bicarbonate 12 mEq/L Chloride 100 mEq/L K 6.4 mEq/L Sodium 126 mEq/L ABG: pH 7.12; partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2 ) 28 mm Hg; partial pressure of oxygen (PO2 ) 95 mm Hg UA: glucose 1000 mg/dL; ketones +++ Acetone, beta-hydroxybutyrate levels: markedly elevated ECG: sinus tachycardia, normal T wave, no ST abnormalities What will be the immediate next step

In continuation of previous case patient was started on iv fluids along with insulin infusion. After 2 hours, the patient’s lethargy resolves, and normal mentation returns. The repeat laboratory test results are: Glucose 245 mg/dL K 4.8 mEq/L Serum bicarbonate 18 mEq/L pH 7.32 What is the biggest change you must make in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Stop IV insulin; switch to subcutaneous delivery.

options.label: D
options.text: Move the patient out of ICU.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes presented to emergency with polyuria, confusion and lethargy for the few day. He stopped taking his medications for 2 weeks. His oral intake is low. On examination-BP-100/60 mmHg, disoriented, ,Chest: clear to auscultation Abdomen: soft, nontender Cardiovascular: no murmur, no gallop. Plasma Glucose 660 mg/dL, Chloride 100 mEq/L, Sodium 125 mEq/L, ABG: pH 7.3; ketones- negative, ECG: sinus tachycardia. What is the mechanism of this decrease in sodium?

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperglycemia pulls water out of cells, diluting out the sodium.

questions.correct_answer: C. Hyperglycemia pulls water out of cells, diluting out the sodium.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with progressively worsening fatigue and tiredness developing over the last several months comes to your OPD. She has also been gaining weight and suffering from constipation.On examination : Respiratory rate: 10 breaths/minute; BP: 130/90 mm Hg; Pulse: 54 beats/minute; Cardiovascular: normal, Abdomen: no organomegaly, decreased bowel sounds diffusely Neurological: decreased relaxation phase of reflexes, Skin: course, thick hair. what is the likely cause for this presentation

A 34-year-old man is brought to the ED by his family because of lethargy. He lives alone and was not answering the phone for several days. His father has to have the lock broken to get into the house. He was found on the floor disoriented and awake only enough to say he is constipated and has abdominal pain. BP: 145/94 mm Hg; P: 86 beats/minute; Neurological: lethargic, unable to follow commands Cardiovascular: normal Abdominal: decreased bowel sounds Extremities: decreased skin turgor. Laboratory Test Results: Total calcium: 16 mg/dL (normal 9−10.5 mg/dL) BUN: 70 g/dL (normal 7−20 g/dL) Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL (normal 0.7−1.2 mg/dL) Bicarbonate: 21mEq/L CBC, transaminases, head CT, and urine toxicology: normal.What will be the best immediate treatment

A 27-year-old woman comes to your of ice concerned that her face is getting “fatter and rounder” despite the fact that she exercises and restricts her diet. She has an increasing acne problem. She was referred to you by her dermatologist who she was seeing for the acne and thinning hair on her scalp. PMHX: Infertility, irregular menstruation Borderline hypertension Vertebral compression fracture. BP: 153/98 mm Hg. General appearance: somewhat obese abdomen Skin: striae on flanks, bruises on thin arms Head, ears, eyes, nose, throat (HEENT): excess hair over lip and at chin Cardiovascular: normal. What is the best initial test to look for hypercortisolism?

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the head

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes comes to the OPD because he has daytime somnolence and his wife complains that he snores, has body odor and having erectile dysfunction. Shoe and ring size started increasing over the last 1 to 2 years. On examination BP: 160/100 mm Hg; General appearance: large nose, lips, and jaw; teeth widely spaced. Thyromegaly present. Chest-clear, CVS- normal. What is the best initial test?

A 45 year old male presented with features of acromegaly. He is c/o tiredness and easy dyspnea for last 6 months. On examination besides acromegaly, thyromegaly and macroglossia also present. On lab tests IGF levels are increased and glucose fails to suppress growth hormones. MRI pituitary showed growth. Patient is also concerned about cancer as there is family history of cancer present. What cancer should you test the patient for?

A 30 year old man presented with complaints of increasing size of hands and feet, hoarseness of voice, excessive snoring. He also c/o dyspnea on exertion and numbness/tingling sensation in hands. On examination acromegaly present and enlarged tongue. Lab results showed elevated IGF, high Hba1c and dyslipidemia. MRI brain showed pituitary adenoma. Surgery is planned for the patient. Patient is asking for results after surgery. Which of the following will most likely resolve after removing the pituitary gland?

A 43-year-old man comes to clinic because of progressive slowness due muscle weakness. It is equal in all four extremities, started 6 months ago, and is slowly progressive and uncomfortable. There is h/o polyuria also. BP: 168/98 mm Hg; P: 72 beats/minute. Cardiovascular: S4 gallop Musculoskeletal: decreased strength throughout. Lab reports- sodium 145 mEq/L; K: 2.4 mEq/L, ECG: U waves present, T4 , TSH, CBC, calcium, phosphorus: normal. You start the treatment and in 2 days patient weakness has improved and U waves in ECG disappeared. What was the treatment ?

A 40 year old female presented with episodes of muscle weakness intermittently for last 1 year.She also gives h/o of polyuria and headache.On examination- edema-absent,BP-130/100 mmHg,Heart-LVS4 present.Lab tests- plasma glucose 90 mg/dl,HbA1c-5.6%,serum creatinine-0.8 mg/dl,Na-140 mmol/L,K-2.3 mmol/L,She was advised to undergo aldosterone and renin levels.Which of the following combinations will makes a diagnosis of primary aldosteronism for her

In continuation to previous question, patient has high aldosterone and low renin. The following week the patient’s salt loading test shows a persistent high aldosterone level despite 5000 mEq/day in the diet. She underwent CT scan of adrenal gland. The adrenal CT shows a bilateral hyperplasia. What will be next appropriate treatment ?

A 34-year-old woman comes to of ice with abnormal milk production from her breasts for the last few weeks. She did three home pregnancy tests and all are negative. She has been unsuccessfully trying to get pregnant for 2 years. Her menstrual periods are irregular. PMHX: Depression Medications: Fluoxetine PE: Normal except galactorrhea. Lab test shows elevated prolactin levels. Which of the following endocrinopathies is associated with high prolactin level?

A young female presented with infertility and excess milk discharge from breasts. She is not taking any medications.There is no significant past or family medical history.Lab tests-Plasma glucose 80 mg/dl,Liver and kidney functions are normal,TSH- 3.0 mIU/L,Pooled prolactin levels are high. An MRI pituitary is done which shows a 5-mm lesion in the pituitary gland. What is the next best step?

A 40 year old female presented with history of easy irritability, nervousness, insomnia, fatigue. She has lost weight but with increased appetite. She has developed oligomenorrhoea for last 3 months. Family history is insignificant. On examination- pulse is 120/min. BP-150/60 mmHg, warm sweaty palms, hand tremor, vitiligo and palmar erythema present. CVS-loud S1 noted. Chest is clear. What will be the next appropriate step
questions.correct_answer: B. Do Free T3,T4 and TSH

questions.text: In continuation with the previous clinical vignette the patient got the thyroid functions tests done with free T3 and free T4 elevated and TSH very low. Thyroid scan done revealed diffuse increase in uptake. A diagnosis of Grave’s thyroiditis was made. Which of the following will be best treatment for her

Patient started on oral antithyroid drug- carbimazole as she refused other form of treatment. But she didn’t come for regular follow up. One year later she complaint of multiple episodes of muscle weakness following excess oral carbohydrate. Each episode of Weakness lasted for 48 hours then subsided. Which is the likely cause of her weakness

options.label: C
options.text: Myasthenia Gravis as its also autoimmune

questions.text: A 30 year old female complaint of dryness of skin, hair loss, cold intolerance, hoarse voice,lethargy, constipation, and menorrhagia.On examination-coarse, dry skin , Loss of outer third of eyebrows.Neck-goitre present which is firm and lobulated.Pulse-56/min,BP-120/90 mmHg,CVS-S1 soft,no murmur,chest-clear,CNS- ankle jerks delayed relaxation.Which test is to be done next

Patient in previous clinical vignette was diagnosed a case of Hashimoto thyroiditis. She was put on thyroxine replacement which she continued without any follow up. But her symptoms didn’t improve. She was also irregular with her thyroxine doses. She now presented with increased lethargy and weakness. You did her lab tests done. What will be the laboratory changes in the patient?

In continuation with previous clinical vignette, Patient tests results showed- elevated TSH, low free T3 and T4,High total cholesterol,high LDL cholesterol.Serum Na-134 mmol/L,prolactin-normal.How would you manage this patient with hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral T4 replacement therapy for life.

questions.correct_answer: A. Oral T4 replacement therapy for life.

questions.text: A 45 year old female presented with lethargy, puffiness of eyes, decrease concentration, memory loss and excessive sleepiness. On examination thyromegaly was present. Lab tests showed low free t4 and high TSH. AntiTPO ab positive. What will be the cardiovascular manifestations in the patient?

A 60 year old female presented to emergency with altered sensorium for last 2 weeks. She is a diagnosed case of Hashimoto thyroiditis. On examination pulse is 50/minute,BP-130/98 mmHg, asterixis is present. Lab test shows elevated TSH and anti TPO ab positive. You made a diagnosis of Hashimoto encephalopathy, Which of the following statement is not true about this condition.

options.label: B
options.text: EEG will show slow wave activity

questions.text: A 30-year-old male complaints of excessive sweating, headaches and numbness of hand for last one year. His wife is noticing that his face and hands are enlarging. One month back he was diagnosed with hypertension. On examination BP-150/100 mmHg, examination hands- excessive sweating and doughy, spatulate fingers, Tinel’s sign is positive. Face: Prominent supraorbital ridges and prognathism, Throat- macroglossia, neck-thyromegaly present. CVS-normal, chest-clear, per abdomen -hepatosplenomegaly present.What will be next investigation to be done
In continuation with previous clinical vignette patient was diagnosed as acromegaly. MRI pituitary revealed macroadenoma. What will be the main therapeutic options for him?

A 26 year old female presented with weakness and easy fatigue. She complains of postural dizziness. She has home delivery 6 months back. On Examination patient is pale; the skin is soft, Paucity of axillary and pubic hair, Atrophy of breast, postural hypotension. visual fields: bitemporal hemianopia present. What is the likely cause of this presentation

options.label: B
options.text: Hypopituitarism secondary to postpartum pituitary necrosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Hypopituitarism secondary to postpartum pituitary necrosis

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presented with history of dizziness, syncope, skin pigmentation, fatigue, weakness, apathy, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, weight loss and abdominal pain for last 3 months. On examination- BP-108/60 mmHg with significant postural drop in BP. Hyperpigmentation localized to palmar creases and knuckles and vitiligo. What will be next line of investigation

A 40 year old female known case of rheumatoid arthritis on chronic steroid therapy now presented with weight gain, easy bruising, and menstrual disturbance. She also complaint of loss of libido, depression and sleep disturbances. On examination-oral cavity: thrush present, interscapular area has buffalo hump,increased fat pads and bulge above supraclavicular fossae.The abdomen has purple striae.The limbs has bruising, wasting and weakness of the muscles of the shoulders and hips.BP-150/90 mmHg.What is the likely cause of this presentation

A 50-year-old male presented with history of chronic intermittent diarrhea, flushing attacks, which are associated with increased lacrimation and periorbital oedema. Flushing is provoked by eating, exertion and alcohol intake. There is wheezing during episodes of flushing. On examination there is flushed face, chest-ronchi, CVS-TR murmur, per abdomen- hepatomegaly. What is the cause of this presentation

A 50-year-old obese woman has long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus inadequately controlled on metformin and pioglitazone. Insulin glargine (15 units subcutaneously at bedtime) has recently been started because of a hemoglobin A1C level of 8.4. Over the weekend, she develops nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after exposure to family members with a similar illness. Afraid of hypoglycemia, the patient omits the insulin for 3 nights. Over the next 24 hours, she develops lethargy and is brought to the emergency room. On examination, she is afebrile and unresponsive to verbal command. Blood pressure is 84/52. Skin turgor is poor and mucous membranes dry. Neurological examination is nonfocal; she does not have neck rigidity. Laboratory results are as follows: Na: 126 mEq/L K: 4.0 mEq/L Cl: 95 mEq/L HCO3 : 22 mEq/L Glucose: 1100 mg/dL BUN: 84 mg/dL Creatinine: 3.0 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s coma?

options.label: C
options.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with a persistent headache for the past few months. The headache has been gradually worsening and is unresponsive to over-the-counter medicines. He notices diminished peripheral vision while driving. He takes no medications. He denies illicit drug use but has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day since the age of 18. His medical history is significant for passage of a kidney stone last year. At that time, he was told to increase his fluid intake. Family history is positive for diabetes in his mother. His brother (age 20) has had kidney stones from too much calcium and a “low-sugar problem.” His father died of some type of tumor at age 40. Physical examination reveals a deficit in temporal fields of vision and a few subcutaneous lipomas. Laboratory results are as follows: Calcium: 11.8 mg/dL(normal 8.5-10.5) Cr: 1.1 mg/dL BUN: 17 mg/dL Glucose: 70 mg/dL Prolactin: 220 pg/L(normal 0-20) Intact parathormone: 90 pg/mL(normal 8-51) You suspect a pituitary tumor and order an MRI which reveals a 0.7 cm pituitary mass. Based on this patient’s presentation, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 50-year-old woman presented in your OPD with Fasting blood glucose of 160 mg/dL and 155 mg/dL on two occasions. HgA1c is 7.9%. You educate the patient on medical nutrition therapy. She returns for reevaluation in 8 weeks. She states she has followed diet and exercise recommendations, but her FBG remains between 140 and 150 and HgA1C is 7.7%. She is asymptomatic, and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?

A 24-year-old woman presents 6 months after the delivery of her first child, a healthy girl, for evaluation of fatigue. She suspects that the fatigue is related to getting up at night to breastfeed her baby, but she has also noticed cold intolerance and mild constipation. She recalls having a tremor and mild palpitations for a few weeks, beginning 3 months after delivery. On examination, her BP is 126/84 and her pulse rate is 56. The thyroid gland is two times normal in size and nontender. The rest of the physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies reveal a free T4 level of 0.7 ng/mL(normal 0.9-2.4) and an elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) at 22 microU/mL(normal 0.4-4). What is the likely course of her illness?

options.label: A
options.text: Permanent hypothyroidism requiring lifelong replacement therapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old white woman presents for an annual examination. She feels well except for occasional nocturnal leg cramp and mild abdominal bloating. She takes a multivitamin and a supplement containing 600 mg calcium carbonate and 200 international units of vitamin D twice daily. She takes no prescription medications. Physical examination is unremarkable for her age. In completing the appropriate screening tests, you order a dual-x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) to evaluate whether the patient has osteoporosis. DEXA results reveal a T-score of –3.0 at the total hip and –2.7 at the femoral neck (osteoporosis: less than –2.5). Since her Z-score is –2.0, you proceed with an evaluation of secondary osteoporosis. Laboratory evaluation reveals Calcium: 8.2 mg/dL Cr: 1.0 mg/dL BUN: 19 mg/dL Glucose: 98 mg/dL 25, OH vitamin D: 12 ng/mL(optimal >30) Liver enzymes including alkaline phosphatase: normal WBC: 7700/μL Hg: 10.3 g/dL HCT: 32 g/dL MCV 68 PLT: 255,000/μL What is the likely cause of her osteoporosis?

A 27-year-old woman presents with palpitations, fatigue, heat intolerance, and insomnia. She has an otherwise unremarkable medical history. She is on no medications and does not use illicit drugs, weight loss products, or caffeine. On physical examination, her extremities are warm and she is tachycardic. Her neck shows diffuse, nontender thyroid enlargement. She has mild proptosis, as well as thickening of the skin in the pretibial area. Her laboratory values show a free T4 value of 3.2 ng/dL(normal 0.9-2.4), and increased radioiodine uptake at 24 hours. Which of the following statements about the pathogenesis of her disease process is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Immune globulins produced in the thyroid, lymph nodes, and bone marrow stimulate the thyroid directly to produce high levels of T4 .

options.label: B
options.text: Antibodies against TSH cause its level to appear low when in reality it is being overproduced, leading to high levels of T4 .

options.label: C
options.text: Microscopic thyroid lesions present in the enlarged thyroid gland produce T4 in an autonomous and unregulated fashion.

options.label: D
options.text: Multiple nodules that will be evident on a thyroid ultrasound secrete a TSH analog which leads to hyperthyroidism.

questions.correct_answer: A. Immune globulins produced in the thyroid, lymph nodes, and bone marrow stimulate the thyroid directly to produce high levels of T4 .

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with dry skin, fatigue, and weight gain over the past 3 months. On examination- Her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 60/min, and heart and lungs are normal. Her skin feels rough and dry, but the rest of the examination is normal. Blood tests shows thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 39 mU/L (normal 0.5–5 mU/L). Which of the following is the most likely cause for her elevated TSH?

A 25-year-old female presented 12 months after delivery. She complaints of weakness, loss of axillary and pubic hairs. She has amenorrhea for last 5 months. On examination pallor is present along with myxedema features. She is emaciated and cachexic. BP-88/60 mmHg,pulse-58/minute. Chest and CVS examination are normal. You are suspecting pituitary hyposecretion. Which of the following is the most common presentation of anterior pituitary hyposecretion in this female?

A 19-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhea. Her physical examination is normal, and she has female sex characteristics and breast development. The only abnormality is the absence of body hair. Genetic testing reveals an XY chromosome pattern. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely to explain her phenotypic pattern and amenorrhea?

A 17-year-old woman has skin photosensitivity since childhood but has gotten worse recently. Her skin appears fine indoors, but within a short period of sun exposure, she develops burning, redness, and itching. A diagnosis of erythropoietic protoporphyria is made by a dermatologist. Which of the following treatments is most likely to be helpful?

A 29-year-old woman presents in OPD with complaints of irregular periods and infertility. Her clinical examination is entirely normal. No features of any genetic disorder seen. Biochemical tests show a reduced estradiol and follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) levels. You made a diagnosis of central hypogonadism. Which of the following is the most important function of FSH?

options.label: C
options.text: Causes the secretory phase of the uterine mucosa

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented for routine health check up. On examination BP-120/70 mmHg,pulse-84/min, chest-clear, CVS-normal. Blood tests showed serum calcium level of 12 mg/dL(normal 8.5-10.5 mg/dl). Further investigations reveal a parathormone (PTH) level of 750 pg/mL (normal 230–630 pg/mL). Which of the following findings is also associated with this disorder?

A 32-year-old woman is feeling unwell because of muscle cramps and generalized fatigue. Her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 100/min, and the heart and lungs are normal. Muscle strength and bulk are normal but the reflexes are increased symmetrically. She had a previous thyroidectomy for a goiter 3 years ago. Her serum calcium level is 7 mg/dL (normal 8.5–10.5 mg/dL), TSH 3 mU/L (0.5–5 mU/L) and albumin 4 g/dL (3.5–5.5 g/dL). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her low calcium?

A 27-year-old woman presents with weight loss, fatigue, and weakness. She also experiences nausea and vomiting but no dysphagia. On physical examination-BP-80/50 mmHg, pulse 88/min, chest is clear on auscultation, CVS-normal. There is increased generalized skin pigmentation. Her serum sodium is 124 meq/L(normal 135-145 meq/L) and potassium is 6.0 meq/L(normal 3.5-5.5 meq/L). Which of the following features is also most likely to be present?

A 50 year old male presented with polyuria and polydipsia.There is no family history of diabetes mellitus.On examination BP-110/80 mmHg.On lab tests urine osmolality is less than 300 which remains low even after fluid deprivation test.After giving desmopressin urine osmolality increased to 500.You made a diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus.You order for MRI of brain. Which of the following is the most likely finding on magnetic resonance imaging of the brain?

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperintense signals in the cerebral cortex

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of hyperintense signals from the posterior pituitary

questions.correct_answer: D. Lack of hyperintense signals from the posterior pituitary

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy was brought to your OPD by parents who are concerned about his weight. On examination he is 5’7” tall and weighs 140 kg. There is no thyromegaly. Chest is clear, CVS-soft heart sounds due to obesity. On lab tests- fasting plasma glucose is 80 mg/dl. No medical cause for this obesity is found. Which of the following abnormalities can he also be expected to have?

A 56-year-old man presents with a change in skin color, fatigue, and abdominal pain. He has also noticed increased urine output and thirst. On examination, his skin appears bronze in color, his liver span is 16 cm, and there is loss of body hair, and testicular atrophy. His ferritin is 600 ng/mL (15–200 ng/mL), aspartate amino transferase (AST) 130 U/L (8–20 U/L), alanine amino transferase (ALT) 150 U/L (8–20 U/L), and total bilirubin 0.5mg/dL (0.1–1 mg/dL). Coagulation tests and albumin level are normal but the random glucose is elevated at 250 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old man has had recurrent attacks of abdominal pain and proximal motor neuropathy since puberty. The episodes are precipitated by infections and certain medications. During one of the attacks, the plasma porphobilinogen levels were increased. You made a diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria. Which of the following medications is not considered safe in patients with this condition?

A 40-year-old man comes to OPD for routine check up.There is no significant past or family history.He doesn’t smoke and take alcohol occasionally.On examination he weighs 85 kg and height is 1.8 m. His calculated body mass index (BMI) is 23 kg/m2.Chest,per abdomen and CVS are within normal limits. Which of the following conditions is he most likely at risk for?
questions.correct_answer: A. No increased risk for mortality

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with bipolar disorder develops new symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia. She has been on lithium for a long time to control her illness. On lab tests-urine output is 5L/day, urine osmolality is 250, plasma fasting glucose is 90 mg/dl and serum sodium is 150 meq/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this complication of lithium treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Impairing glucose absorption at the cellular leve

options.label: D
options.text: Impairing vasopressin action at the tubular level

questions.correct_answer: D. Impairing vasopressin action at the tubular level

questions.text: The 2-year-old daughter of a couple develops progressive loss of motor skills. There is macular pallor on ophthalmic examination, and she has a short stature, thin limbs, but full cheeks. She is also prone to developing hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is most likely associated with this disorder?

A 63-year-old man develops edema, and dyspnea on exertion. He has no prior cardiac or renal conditions, and his examination is significant for macroglossia, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), hepatomegaly, and 3+ pedal edema. His investigations reveal 3.5 g/d of protein in the urine, anemia, normal fasting glucose, and serum immunoelectrophoresis is positive for a monoclonal immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presents with recurrent flushing, diarrhea, and weight loss. On examination pulse is 110/min, BP-100/70 mmHg, chest-rhonchi present bilaterally, CVS-tricuspid regurgitation murmur is seen. Lab investigations reveal an elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old woman presents with symptoms of polyuria and polydipsia. She is not taking any medicines and there is no significant past medical history. On lab reports- 24 hour urine is 4 Litres. Plasma glucose is normal. So far investigations have ruled out psychogenic causes and diabetes. A fluid deprivation test is performed. At the end of the test, the urine osmolality is 240 mOsm/kg and the serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) level is elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 40-year-old man came for routine health check up. Examination showed tendon xanthomas. On lab investigations-increased cholesterol, increased low-density lipoprotein [LDL], and normal triglycerides were reported. You are suspecting a case of familial hypercholesterolemia. Your consultant ask you to rule out secondary causes of hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause secondary hyperlipidemia?

A 61-year-old woman with poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes is seen in follow-up. Her blood sugars are persistently elevated to levels greater than 200 mg/dL. On examination, she is obese, blood pressure 165/90 mm Hg, pulse 80/min, and there is sensory loss in the feet.Fundus examination showed diabetes retinopathy.Urine albumin creatinine ratio is 500 mg/g. Which of the following fasting lipid profiles is most likely to be consistent with her values?

options.label: A
options.text: High total cholesterol, low LDL, and normal triglycerides

options.label: B
options.text: High total cholesterol, high ldl, low triglycerides

options.label: C
options.text: High total cholesterol, normal LDL, high triglycerides

options.label: D
options.text: High total cholesterol, low HDL, and high triglycerides

questions.correct_answer: D. High total cholesterol, low HDL, and high triglycerides

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for back pain and fatigue. He was previously healthy. On examination, he is pale, there is lumbar spine tenderness, and an enlarged liver (18 cm). He is pancytopenic, and there is a vertebral fracture on lumbar x-rays. A bone marrow biopsy reveals infiltration with lipid-laden macrophages (Gaucher cells). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 19-year-old man has early fatigue and muscle cramps while playing sports. He is fine when walking or doing light levels of work. On examination, he appears well and the muscle strength in the proximal muscles is normal. There is no muscle fatigue with repetitive arm grip exercises. After an exercise stress test, his serum creatine kinase is elevated and lactate level is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man develops severe left flank pain that radiates to the front inguinal region. The pain eventually subsides after the passage of “sand-like” urine. He also complaint of red colored urine. There is family history of renal stones in younger brother. Per abdomen examination is normal. A urinalysis reveals flat hexagonal plate like crystals as shown in figure.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased cystine concentration in the urine

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased cystine concentration in the urine

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased cystine concentration in the urine

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with feeling tired and unsteady on his feet. He has a poor appetite and has lost 5 kg weight in 6 months. On examination, he appears cachectic, his heart and lungs are normal, but his liver span is 18 cm. His lab tests show a very low magnesium level of 0.7 mEq/L. On further questioning, he reports drinking heavily since losing his job. ECG showed prolong QT interval. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his low magnesium level?

A 27-year-old woman presents with feeling unwell ever since going on a high vitamin diet. She has dry skin, vomiting, headaches, and amenorrhea. On examination-sparse and coarse hairs are present. Per abdomen- hepatosplenomegaly is present. chest and CVS is normal. Lab results showed leukopenia, anemia, hypercalcemia and increased lipid profile. X ray showed periosteal changes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 12 year old boy was brought to OPD by parents with short height. On examination deformity in hands is present as shown in the figure. He is developmentally short, stocky build. His face is rounded. On lab investigations-serum calcium is low with high PTH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old man comes for routine check up. He is asymptomatic. Family history is significant for premature coronary artery disease in father(starting from the age of 40 years).On lab tests his lipid levels reveal an elevated total and LDL cholesterol. The high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and triglyceride values are normal. His physical examination is completely normal. Which of the following is the most common cause of genetic dyslipidemia?

A 48-year-old woman known case of type 2 diabetes for 15 years presents with lesions on her leg. There is no history of fever. On examination-skin lesions are not tender and have a central depression and raised irregular margin. Lab tests showed Hba1c-10 %.Lipid profile is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency room with severe pain in his right toe. He has had less severe episodes in the past, which he always treated with pain medications. The toe is red, inflamed, and exquisitely sensitive to movement. Needle aspiration of the toe confirms uric acid crystals, and he is treated with oral indomethacin. One month later, he remains symptom free, and allopurinol is recommended for prevention of this condition. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of allopurinol?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased renal tubular secretion of uric acid

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presented with fatigue,anorexia and lethargy for one year.On examination-skin is dry with pruritis marks.Lab tests revealed Hba1c 9.0%,plasma glucose 200 mg/dl,serum creatinine 2.5 mg/dl,BUN 60 mg/dl,Hb 9.3 g/dl,serum PO4 8.0(elevated) and serum calcium 8.0 mg/dl(low).You made a clinical diagnosis of chronic kidney disease. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this electrolyte disturbance?

A 22-year-old man presented to OPD.He gives history of dyspnea on exertion and occasional palpitations.His father died of aortic dissection.On examination he has features of arm span greater than height, subluxed lenses, flattened corneas.CVS-early diastolic murmur at right sternal border suggestive of aortic regurgitation is auscultated.On chest x ray dilation of the aortic ring is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old man is complaining of feeling thirsty all the time and passing more urine than usual. His physical examination is normal. His serum sodium is 150 mEq/L, glucose 120 mg/dL, and osmolality 315 mOsm/kg. The urine sodium is 20 mEq/L and osmolality 260 mOsm/kg. Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause this disorder?

A 20-year-old woman is complaining of passing large amounts of urine. She is otherwise well and her physical examination is normal. The serum sodium is 140 mEq/L and the urinalysis is negative for protein and glucose. The urine sodium is 33 mEq/L, and urine osmolality is 268 mOsm/kg. She weighs 60 kg, and her 24-hour urine output is over 4 L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 62-year-old man comes for routine health check up.He is asymptomatic.He doesn’t smoke and takes alcohol.There is no significant past medical history.There is no family history of chronic disease.He usually order outside food and is sedentary.On examination pulse is 80/min,BP-120/70 mmHg,chest and cvs examination is normal.Blood testing reveals elevated LDL cholesterol. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the elevated LDL?

A 63-year-old asymptomatic woman comes for routine health check up.There is no significant past medical history.She follows a good exercise regimen.She is not taking any medications or supplements.On examination BP-130/60 mmHg,pulse is 80/min and is bounding in nature.Lab tests showed high alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level,other liver function tests are normal. X-rays of the pelvis show multiple porotic and sclerotic lesions with characteristic whorls of trabeculation. Her excretion of urinary hydroxyproline is also elevated. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man presented with symptoms of weakness with numbness and tingling in his hands. He also complaint of perioral numbness. Past medical history is not significant for diabetes, hypertension and hypothyroidism. He doesn’t take alcohol. The physical examination showed Chvostek sign positive. Blood tests revealed calcium as 7.4 mg/dL (normal 8.5–10.5 mg/dL).You are suspecting vitamin D deficiency as a cause of hypocalcemia. Which of the following additional serum values is most consistent with the diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency?

options.label: A
options.text: Low vitamin D, low phosphate, high PTH

options.label: B
options.text: Low vitamin D, low phosphate, low PTH

options.label: C
options.text: Low vitamin D, high phosphate, low PTH

options.label: D
options.text: Normal vitamin D, low phosphate, high PTH

questions.correct_answer: A. Low vitamin D, low phosphate, high PTH

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman complaint of weight loss, tremor, and heat intolerance for last 3 months.There is family history of Graves thyroiditis. On examination pulse is 120/min,BP-150/60 mmHg,chest clear,CVS-no murmurs.She has goiter, warm skin, and a fine tremor of her hands.On lab tests TSH is low and her free T4 and T3 are elevated.TSH receptor ab are positive. Which of the following cardiac findings is most likely to occur in her?

A thyroid nodule is found on a 40-year-old woman on routine evaluation. She has no prior history of thyroid disease and clinically feels well. Family history is not significant for any thyroid diseases. There is a 15-mm nontender nodule on the right lobe of the thyroid with no associated lymphadenopathy. Thyroid function tests are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 42-year-old woman develops light-headed episodes associated with sweating, palpitations, and hunger whenever she misses a meal. There is no past medical history of diabetes or hypertension. Her physical examination is normal, and she is not taking any medications. On one such episode, while in hospital, her blood glucose level was 30 mg/dL and the symptoms resolved with giving her juice. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Tumor of the pancreatic beta-cells

questions.text: A 63-year-old presented with complaint of new onset fatigue and dyspnea on exertion. Recently he noticed black discoloration around eyes as shown in figure. On examination macroglossia seen, CVS-S4 is auscultated.Lab tests showed M spike in serum protein electrophoresis,Bence Jones proteinuria.Abdominal fat pad biopsy confirm the diagnosis of amyloidosis. In which of the following organs, is deposition of amyloid protein most likely to cause symptoms?

A 25-year-old woman presents with intermittent symptoms of sweating, palpitations, and hunger. There is no history of diabetes or hypertension. During each episode pulse is 130/min, BP-140/70 mmHg. On blood tests her glucose level is less than 40 mg/dL. Her insulin level is low and glucagon level is high. Which of the following best describes the hormone function of glucagon?

options.label: C
options.text: Effective in lowering blood sugar levels

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman notices lumps on her elbows and yellow patches below her eyelids. On examination, she has tendon xanthomas on her elbows and xanthelasma under the eyelids. BP-120/80 mmHg. Liver function tests are within normal range. Plasma fasting glucose is 80 mg/dl. Thyroid functions are normal. Her lipid profile is consistent with a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (increased LDL). Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of this condition is correct?

options.label: B
options.text: Cholestyramine is as effective as hepatic hydroxymethylglutaryl-coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) reductase inhibitors (statins)

options.label: C
options.text: Ninety percent of patients can be controlled with a statin

questions.correct_answer: D. Combined therapy is frequently required

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of pain epigastrium for many years. Intermittently he complaint of episodes of tremors and sweating with low plasma glucose levels. He gives family history of some neuroendocrine tumor in elder brother. On examination-no abnormality detected. Lab tests revealed high levels of PTH and c peptide levels. You are suspecting a diagnosis of MEN 1, Which of the following is the most common manifestation of multiple endocrine neoplasia, type I (MEN I)?

A 51-year-old woman presented in OPD with complaints of irregular periods for the past 6 months. Periods are delayed by 15-20 days with spotting. She also has symptoms of hot flashes and night sweats. Her physical examination is normal. Blood tests are normal for plasma glucose, CBC, thyroid functions and liver function test. You decided to start Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for her symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely additional benefit of HRT?

A 37-year-old woman presents with symptoms of fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight gain. She has no past medical history and is not taking any medications. On examination, her blood pressure is 164/92 mm Hg and pulse 84/min. She has multiple skin bruises, facial fullness, and truncal obesity with red “stretch marks.” Muscle strength in the proximal muscles is 4+/5 and reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

options.label: A
options.text: Computerized tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman develops headache, increased hand and foot size. On examination, she has spade like hands, coarsened facial features, and a gap between her incisors. Her blood pressure is 155/85 mm Hg and pulse 80/min, macroglossia and thyromegaly is present.cardiac apical beat is sustained with normal heart sounds. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this syndrome on the muscles?

A 7-year-old boy complaint of bone pains. His parents noticed bowing of legs. His elder brother has similar bone disorder. There is alopecia on clinical examination .X ray showed demineralized bones with pseudo fractures. Serum calcium and phosphorus are low. PTH is raised. Physiologic doses of vitamin D do not result in improvement. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this syndrome?

An 18-year-old girl is brought to hospital because of weakness. She feels well, but is under a lot of stress at school. Most of her time is spent studying, dieting, and exercising. She is 5’8”, weighs 40 kg, and appears unwell. Her blood pressure is 86/70 mm Hg, pulse 50/min, and there is muscle wasting. Which of the following is this patient most likely at risk for?

A 63-year-old man develops severe pain, redness, and swelling in his left big toe. Past medical history is positive for type 2 diabetes, CAD and hypertension. He is smoker and drinks alcohol daily. On examination left great toe is tender with erythema.BP-160/100 mmHg. Blood tests showed elevated LDL cholesterol and serum uric acid. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this condition?

A 27-year-old woman complains of pain in her left shin. Her sunlight exposure is minimal. X-rays of the leg reveal a stress fracture of the tibia, decreased cortical bone density, and increased radiolucency. She is suspected of having osteomalacia (impaired mineralization of bone matrix). Which of the following is the most common biochemical manifestation of osteomalacia?

A 44-year-old man presents with worsening abdominal distension, edema, and jaundice. He has chronic viral hepatitis B and cirrhosis. Recently he has noticed decreased urine output despite adequate fluid intake. On examination he is icteric, the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 74/min, JVP is 4 cm, heart sounds are normal, and there are tense ascites and pedal edema. You made a diagnosis of hepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following is an early manifestation of hepatorenal syndrome?

A 1 year old child brought by parents with vomiting, mousy odor and seizures. On examination skin is fair with blue eyes. Phenylalanine levels are elevated. You made a clinical diagnosis of phenylketonuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for phenylketonuria?

A 21-year-old woman on no medications develops rigidity, tremor, and incoordination. She has a history of unexplained hepatitis 2 years ago and depression 1 year ago. Her examination is pertinent for increased tone, normal muscle strength, and coarse tremor of the hands. An ophthalmologic examination is positive for a brownish pigmented ring at the corneal margin. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 57-year-old man complains of increased thirst and urination. He has to wake up 3-4 times in night. He noticed blurring of vision for last 3 months. His father and brother has type 2 diabetes. He is sedentary. In last one year his stress levels are increased due to job profile. His examination showed acanthosis nigricans and obesity (BMI>30). Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?

A 32-year-old woman presents with heat intolerance, palpitations, diarrhea, weakness, and weight loss. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and she has a fine tremor in her hands. The TSH level is suppressed and T3 and T4 are elevated. Which of the following is most likely to precipitate this condition?

A 15-year-old youth presented to OPD with his parents as he has not developed facial hairs. His voice is not hoarse unlike his batchmates in school. His father also gives history of delayed puberty. On examination his axillary hairs are sparse with no facial hairs. His vitals are normal. Blood tests showed normal testosterone and LH levels for his age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman was diagnosed as case of chronic kidney disease. She is now put on hemodialysis in view of refractory metabolic acidosis and fluid overload. She complains of pain in the hands. On examination, the joints are normal with no inflammation or tenderness on palpation. Lab values reveal a low calcium, high phosphate, and high PTH level. What is the most likely diagnosis

A 35-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weakness, and weight gain for last 2 months. Her blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg, pulse 80/min, and there is central obesity with skin striae. Moon facies is noticed. Investigations are shown.

options.label: A
options.text: Adrenal hyperplasia secondary to hypothalamic dysfunction

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese woman complains of dry mouth, excessive urination. He has lost 5 kg weight in last 3 months in spite of large appetite. She has vulvar pruritus with white curdy discharge. There are symptoms of numbness in hands and feet. There is family history diabetes mellitus in siblings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old man with Type 2 diabetes for last 10 years. He notices painless skin lesions on his legs.On examination BP-150/100 mmHg,pulse is 90/min,afebrile.Local examination of leg showed an irregular raised border with a flat depressed center that is hyperpigmented brown in color.Lab tests- HbA1c-9.6%,fasting plasma glucose 200 mg/dl,CBC is normal.What is the likely diagnosis

A 60-year-old man with Type 2 diabetes comes for routine check up. Physical examination is normal. Blood tests revealed HbA1c 8.0%,urine albumin creatinine ratio 400 mg/g. You advised him to go for fundus check up. The ophthalmologist reports that the patient has developed non proliferative retinopathy. What can be the possible findings in retina

A 35-year-old woman with Type 1 diabetes for 20 years. She has uncontrolled glucose and complaint of osmotic symptoms and frothy urine. She was also diagnosed with diabetes nephropathy last year. Now she develops progressive vision loss in her left eye. The ophthalmologist reports the development of proliferative retinopathy. What will be likely findings in retina

A 15-year-old girl has been losing weight and exercising vigorously. She feels overweight and wants to lose more weight. On examination, she is thin with muscle wasting. Her BMI is 15. Her BP is 84/60 mmHg,pulse-56/min, no thyromegaly, skin is coarse and dry. Which of the following physical signs is also suggestive of the diagnosis?

A 17-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of weakness and weight loss. He is diagnosed with an eating disorder and admitted to the hospital. He is cachexic, dry skin, brittle hairs, BP-80/50 mmHg, pulse 60/min, chest-clear, CVS-normal, per abdomen is soft. Which of the following lab values is not consistent with this diagnosis?

A 22-year-old woman is brought to hospital because of syncope. There were no warning symptoms, and she was fine after the event. Recently she has lost 20 kg because of an eating disorder. She weighs 35 kg, looks unwell, and has little muscle bulk. The blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg and pulse 50/min. Which of the following is the most likely abnormality on her ECG?

A 64-year woman with Type 2 diabetes for 10 years now develops increasing fatigue, dyspnea, and pedal edema. On examination, her blood pressure is 166/90 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, JVP is 4 cm above sternal angle, heart sounds are normal, lungs are clear, and there is 3+ pedal edema. HbA1c is 8.5 %,fasting plasma glucose is 180 mg/dl. Her urinalysis is positive for 3+ protein and no casts. Which of the following renal diseases is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

An 83-year-old man with poor nutrition notices easy bruising and bleeding gums. On examination, he has inflamed bleeding gums, multiple areas of ecchymoses, and perifollicular hemorrhages. His coagulation profile and liver function is normal. Bleeding time is increased, CBC including platelet count is normal. What is the likely deficiency leading to this clinical presentation?

A 43-year-old woman with chronic alcoholism presents with shortness of breath and edema. On examination, her blood pressure is 150/60 mm Hg, pulse 110/min and is bounding, JVP is 8 cm above sternal angle, Pedal edema is present. Cardiac apex is displaced and is hyperdynamic. Chest has bilateral inspiratory crackles, and there is pedal edema. What is the likely vitamin deficiency present?

A 52-year-old alcoholic notices a skin rash on his chest, and also has symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, he has a scaly and pigmented rash on the sun-exposed areas of his skin, the abdomen is soft, and his short-term memory is impaired. He has dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia syndrome.
